text.p:
Exciton-polaritons are very promising bosonic quasiparticles for displaying collective phenomena at high temperatures.
Currently the most widely used approach to model a system of interacting Bose particles is based on solution of the
Gross-Pitaevskii equation [1]. However, this approach has several drawbacks. First, it assumes complete coherence in
the system and processes of polariton-phonon scattering can hardly be accounted for properly. Second, the intermediate
regime (when Bose-Einstein condensate is not have been formed yet) can not be investigated.

This background encouraged us to develop a new approach that merges profits of the GPe with those of quasi-classical
Boltzman equation [2]. We strongly believe that state correlations should be considered explicitly and therefore
consider the system of interacting particles and keep track of the time evolution of both state populations and the
correlators between them. In the 1D channel the polariton-polariton and polariton-phonon interactions are accounted
for in respective appropriate ways [3]. Coherent processes (free propagation of the particles, polariton-polariton
interactions) areconsidered using Liouville-von Neumann equation (see ref. [3] for details) whereas processes of
polaritons on phonons scattering, loosing decoherence, are described by dint of Born-Markov approximation.

The formalism is suitable for arbitrary dimensions, but we focus on polaritons in a 1D channel. Fig. 1 is an illustration
of the hysteresis that occurs when pumping at some k (the pump is in units µeV /¯ h) for different temperatures. The
temperature dependence saturates above T 5 K, and the curves look more or less the same. On Fig. 2 one can see
the transport of a polariton droplet at t = 0.5 ps (inset) and t = 1.5 ps (main plot). The red curve corresponds to T = 1
K and there is a significant backscattered packet due to polariton-polariton interaction. Increasing the temperature
up to T = 20 K (black) this is suppressed by smoothing.
